results.title: Branded to kill [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Seijun Suzuki, Kaneo Iwai and Nikkatsu Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: Hanado Goro, no. 3 gunman in the Tokyo underworld after killing no. 2 and bungling the fourth of a series of imaginatively executed ‘hits’, finds himself playing cat-and-mouse with the dangerous no. 1. Explosions of violence are punctuated by moments of unexpected lyricism and intermingled with bizarre humour (Hanado is sexually aroused by the smell of boiled rice). After making dozens of run-of-the-mill genre films for Nikkatsu, Sejun Suzuki began transforming the banal material assigned to him into farcically hyperbolic absurdist thrillers reinventing the yakuza film by drawing on Japanese comical literary, theatrical and cinematic traditions (see also “Tokyo drifter”), in the process attracting both a cult following and the ire of Nikkatsu. Cast includes Jo Shishido, Koji Nanbara, Isao Tamagawa, Annu Mari, Mariko Ogawa and Hiroshi Minami. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Branded Si-Ro-Mark
results.creator_credit: Frank Land and Australian Wool Board
results.brief_description: Each year, great damage is done to the Australian wool clip by branding fluids. At wool sales, the price for marked wool decreases and in scouring and milling processes later, it is impossible to remove all the dirty wool, resulting in the needless waste of finished woollen goods. The CSIRO has developed an accurable and permanent branding fluid, “Si-Ro-Mark” and its wide-spread use to replace tar, sump-oil and other unsatisfactory fluids is advocated, not only in the interests of the grower but also the Australian wool and woollen textile industry as a whole.

results.title: Brand new key
results.brief_description: A lively animation based on Melanie’s popular song, finds the female lead skating into her boyfriends affections. A short, amusing film with uncluttered animation. Title song sung by Cher.

results.title: Branchline railway
results.brief_description: Michael Palin, confessed train buff, introduces unique footage from the BBC archive: Branchline Railway and two historic newsreel sequences - a splendid requiem for the steam railway. “Branchline Railway”: the late Sir John Betjeman presents this little known film which perfectly captures the atmosphere of a 24 mile stretch of the now vanished Somerset and Dorset railway. It celebrates a working, living railway, complete with dirty locomotives, clean stations decked with flowers, and austere gas-lit waiting rooms. It all belongs to a vanished age but the film remains to delight and inform (broadcast 1963). “Britannia under her own steam” looks at the naming of the first magnificent Class 7 4-6-2 Standard locomotives ‘Britannia’ (broadcast 1951). “Atlantic Coast Express” is a footplate journey on Merchant Navy Class No. 35016 ‘Elder Fyffe’ as it heads the ‘Atlantic Coast Express’ (broadcast 1960).

results.title: Branching out
results.creator_credit: Bill Latto and Town and Country Productions
results.brief_description: Shows how the four senior branch sections of the Girl Guide Associations - Air, Land, and Sea Rangers and Cadets, provide modern and lively training with popular appeal for the teenage girl. Training includes gliding, rock climbing, flower arranging, pony trekking, boating, music appreciation, hostessing and welfare work. An International Mixed Camp provides the girls wiht an opportunity of mixing with their contemporaries from other countries.

results.title: Bram Stoker's Dracula [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola, Charles Mulvehill, Fred Fuchs, Osiris Films and American Zoetrope
results.brief_description: Francis Ford Coppola’s lavish new version of Bram Stoker’s classic novel is visually stunning, filled with images of both beauty and horror. James V. Hart’s screenplay sticks fairly close to Stoker’s novel although costuming and special effects give this film a very definite contemporary feel. Dracula is played brilliantly by Gary Oldman, and his arch-rival Dr. Van Helsing is played by Sir Anthony Hopkins. Cast also includes Winona Ryder and Keanu Reeves.

results.title: Brake free
results.brief_description: This film is designed to encourage imagination and story telling by children. A small boy imagines himself as a railwayman, a train and a driver of the old cog railway that climbs Mt Washington. No narration or dialogue - only sound effects and a musical score.

results.title: Braindead = Dead alive (D)
results.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, Jim Booth and Wingnut Films
results.brief_description: New Zealand director Peter Jackson has aptly described “Braindead’s” anarchic style as splatstick, an outrageous melding of extreme gore and physical humour. While it does go to great lengths to gross you out (you’ll never eat porridge again!), it still finds time to be a rather sweet love story, as well as a titanic Oedipal struggle between mother and son. Set in the latter part of the fifties, “Braindead” concerns momma’s boy Lionel’s (Timothy Balme) feeble attempts to break away from his domineering mother (Elizabeth Moody), while a romance develops between him and local shop girl, Paquita (Diana Penalver). The situation gets messy however when Lionel’s mother is bitten by a strange rat like monkey (captured in a very funny opening sequence) which turns her into one of the living dead. When Lionel’s lecherous uncle Les (Ian Watkin) shows up unexpectedly, all hell breaks loose and soon the place is swarming with zombies.

results.title: Brain story. Eps. 04-06
results.creator_credit: Zoe Heron, Thecla Schreuders, Sam Roberts and BBC
results.brief_description: Brain Story is a series of six programs exploring the latest research on brain function. Professor Susan Greenfield CBE, presenter of the series, uses current scientific technology to help answer a number of philosophical questions about who we are as people and what makes you ‘you’ and the brain’s role in this. Episode 4: “First amongst equals” investigates why humans use their brains beyond survival instincts. The frontal lobes in our brain controls our ability to plan and make goals. An extensive study of chimpanzees and their language ability is used to illustrate the difference between animal and human brain function and why we as humans seek to excel beyond survival. Episode 5: “Growing the mind” explores how memory is developed throughout our lives, the physical conditions to facilitate this in the brain and how beyond ‘semantic memory’ our memory defines us as individuals. Episode 6: “The Final mystery” explores vividly how the brain creates the conscious experience of being you. Greenfield establishes how our daily actions are the result of slowly emerging sub-conscious processes in the brain. (Episode 6 features The Jim Rose Circus).
